elements.content: Employing a solvothermal procedure and use of p-tert-butyl-thiacalix[4]arene tetraacetic acid (H4 TCTA) and the nitrate salts of cobalt(II) and cadmium(II) have enabled isolation of four three-dimensional metal–organic frameworks (1–4) in the presence of three different types of neutral bridging coligands. In one case, 3, a mixed metal ion system (Co2+/Na+) was obtained. First, the reaction of H4 TCTA with Co(NO3)2·6H2O together with the linear bridging coligand BPY (4,4′-bipyridine) afforded a mixture of two 3D frameworks of types [Co2(TCTA)(BPY)] n (1) and [Co2(TCTA)(BPY)2(H2O)4] n (2). Compound 1 features a paddle-wheel unit incorporating Co2+ pairs, Co2(carboxylate)4, involving four different TCTA units in two dimensions and BPY pillaring in the third. In 2, 2D sheets consisting of BPY–Co repeating chains stacked in an A-B-A-B pattern are pillared by TCTA to yield the 3D motif. In the second reaction system, the use of H4 TCTA with Co(NO3)2·6H2O in the presence of the bent bridging coligand BPPA (N,N′-bis(pyridine-4-yl)-isophthalamine) and NaOH afforded {[Co3Na2(TCTA)2(BPPA)2(H2O)2]·4DMF·4H2O} n (3). In 3, TCTA yields a honeycomb-shaped 2D sheet via Co–O(carboxylate) bonds; these sheets are linked by Co–O(carboxylate) and Co–(BPPA)–Co bridging bonds to afford the 3D motif. In this case, the Na atom locates inside the calix cavity in a distorted square planar coordination environment and is stabilized by η3-type cation···π interactions. In the third system, the use of H4 TCTA with Cd(NO3)2·6H2O in the presence of the flexible bridging coligand diaminohexane (DAH) gave {[Cd2(TCTA)(DAH)(DMF)2]·2DMF·2H2O} n (4), which features an unusual PtS-like 3D structure. The results confirm that the nature of the extended 3D structures is influenced by the bridging coordination behavior of the coligands. In all these structures, the TCTA ligands adopt a 1,3-alternate conformation. Thermal gravimetric analysis performed on the present MOFs revealed that three of these compounds have high thermal stability (∼300 °C).

elements.content: In recent years, the synthesis and investigation of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) exhibiting higher dimensional structures have become one of the most active fields in coordination/materials chemistry. The preparation of MOFs can be influenced by many factors such as the nature of both the metal ion and the main ligand present, the anion type, any linker coligands employed and the reaction conditions. In modulating the resultant topologies of MOFs, the use of organic ligands with appropriate backbone structures is clearly important. In this regard, the use of a ligand derivative incorporating a well-established macrocyclic receptor system has proved to be an effective strategy that merges the chemistry of MOFs with supramolecular chemistry.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the synthesis and investigation of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) exhibiting higher dimensional structures have become one of the most active fields in coordination/materials chemistry. The preparation of MOFs can be influenced by many factors such as the nature of both the metal ion and the main ligand present, the anion type, any linker coligands employed and the reaction conditions. In modulating the resultant topologies of MOFs, the use of organic ligands with appropriate backbone structures is clearly important. In this regard, the use of a ligand derivative incorporating a well-established macrocyclic receptor system has proved to be an effective strategy that merges the chemistry of MOFs with supramolecular chemistry.

elements.content: Calixarenes represent one of the most popular macrocyclic scaffolds used in the construction of supramolecular assemblies. Corresponding thiacalixarenes differ in their connector units from those in calixarenes: the repeated phenolic units linked by CH2 bridges in the latter are replaced by S atoms in the former, while similar cyclic conformations are retained in both. However, NMR studies have revealed that thiacalixarenes are conformationally more flexible than their calixarene analogs. Sometimes thiacalix[4]arene and its derivatives show a 1,3-alternate conformation, both in solution and in the solid state. Due to the presence of a cavity and two phenol groups positioned at each end in this case, like calix[4]arene, thiacalix[4]arene is a promising scaffold for attaching additional functionality at both ends. For example, the modification of the pairs of phenol groups to yield appended carboxylic groups could be advantageous over a pending neutral functional groups because it may avoid the necessity for coordination of a counterion, which sometimes inhibits the generation of a desired higher dimension species.

Due to the presence of a cavity and two phenol groups positioned at each end in this case, like calix[4]arene, thiacalix[4]arene is a promising scaffold for attaching additional functionality at both ends. elements.content: In a related study of the networking of (thia)calixarene derivatives, the Hosseini and Kalchenko groups reported the silver(I), cobalt(II), and nickel(II) coordination polymers with 1D or 2D structures. However, other examples of coordination polymers based on (thia)calixarene derivatives are still rare. Furthermore, there have been no reports of the formation of coordination polymers of (thia)calixarene derivatives in the presence of a coligand system.

However, other examples of coordination polymers based on (thia)calixarene derivatives are still rare. Furthermore, there have been no reports of the formation of coordination polymers of (thia)calixarene derivatives in the presence of a coligand system.

elements.content: Our interest in this area has recently led us to investigate new types of coordination polymers derived from p-tert-butyl-thiacalix[4]arene tetraacetic acid (H4 TCTA, Scheme ) in which the metal ions are not only accommodated inside the cavity but also to link the “endocalix” complex units to give a network structure involving carboxyl groups that are appended to the respective phenol positions; carboxylate pendant derivatives of this type have been extensively used previously for the construction of higher dimensional networks, reflecting this group’s variable coordination modes including its bridging ability. On the other hand, a number of bidentate diamine derivatives or their ammonium analogs have been used not only as important building blocks for the construction of organic supramolecules including rotaxanes but also as coligands for the MOFs. Based on these considerations, we have coupled this approach with employing neutral bridging coligands such as BPY, BPPA, and DAH not only as linkers between the metal ion centers but also to act as bases to promote carboxylic acid deprotonation to assist metalation at these sites (Scheme ). In this work, the above strategy has enabled us to employ one-pot reactions to obtain four distinct 3D products, 1–4, with different infinite structures.

elements.content: All chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were measured with a ThermoFisher Scientific Nicolet iS 10 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellet in the range 4000–400 cm–1. Each product obtained in this work was dried in a vacuum before elemental analysis, which was carried out on a LECO CHNS-932 elemental analyzer. TGA was performed on a TA Instruments TGA-Q50 thermogravimetric analyzer in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

All chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were measured with a ThermoFisher Scientific Nicolet iS 10 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellet in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Each product obtained in this work was dried in a vacuum before elemental analysis, which was carried out on a LECO CHNS-932 elemental analyzer. TGA was performed on a TA Instruments TGA-Q50 thermogravimetric analyzer in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1.

elements.content: A mixture of H4 TCTA (20 mg, 0.021 mmol), BPY (7 mg, 0.045 mmol), and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (14 mg, 0.048 mmol) dissolved in DMF (2 mL) was placed in a 5 mL Pyrex glass tube and sealed. The tube was kept at 110 °C for 48 h, followed by cooling to room temperature over 5 h. Two kinds of crystals (both suitable for X-ray analysis) were obtained; blue plates, 1, were obtained immediately after cooling to room temperature, and then yellow crystals, 2, were obtained after 1 week following slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature. (1) Anal. Calcd for C58H60Co2O12N2S4 (%): C, 56.95; H, 4.94; N, 2.29; S, 10.48. Found: C, 56.58; H, 5.15; N, 2.72; S, 10.45. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3432, 2961, 1641, 1611, 1432, 1420, 1384, 1325, 1266, 1229, 1092, 1035, 813, 764, 649. Mp: 324–325 °C (decomp.). (2) Anal. Calcd for C68H76Co2N4O16S4 (%): C, 56.27; H, 5.28; N, 3.86; S, 8.84. Found: C, 56.30; H, 5.48; N, 4.40; S, 8.72. elements.content: All data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX2 ULTRA diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source at 173(2) K. The frame data were processed to give structure factors using SAINT-plus. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 for all data using SHELXTL software. All p-tert-butyl groups in 1 and 2 and one p-tert-butyl group in 3 are disordered over two positions. The disorder components were found from difference electron density maps and refined with fractional occupancies. In 3, the carbon atoms of one DMF molecule are disordered over two positions with occupancies of 0.57:0.43. Since the solvent molecules in 2 were highly disordered, the contribution of solvent electron density was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The positions of the hydrogen atoms for water molecules, except 3, were located from the difference electron density maps and refined using a riding model. In 3, the hydrogen atoms of lattice water molecules were not found from the difference electron density map. All others were placed in calculated positions and refined with a riding model. The crystallographic data for 1–4 are summarized in Table .

X-ray Crystallography

All data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX2 ULTRA diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source at 173(2) K. The frame data were processed to give structure factors using SAINT-plus. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 for all data using SHELXTL software. All p-tert-butyl groups in 1 and 2 and one p-tert-butyl group in 3 are disordered over two positions. The disorder components were found from difference electron density maps and refined with fractional occupancies. In 3, the carbon atoms of one DMF molecule are disordered over two positions with occupancies of 0.57:0.43. Since the solvent molecules in 2 were highly disordered, the contribution of solvent electron density was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The positions of the hydrogen atoms for water molecules, except 3, were located from the difference electron density maps and refined using a riding model. In 3, the hydrogen atoms of lattice water molecules were not found from the difference electron density map. All others were placed in calculated positions and refined with a riding model. The crystallographic data for 1-4 are summarized in Table .

All complexes were obtained as crystalline products by the solvothermal reaction of H4 TCTA and the required metal nitrate with BPY, BPPA, or DAH in DMF. In order to successfully prepare the complexes, it was found important to maintain weakly basic reaction conditions by employing basic coligands (as well as using the basic DMF solvent); the exception was for 3. In this latter case, it was found necessary to add a small amount of NaOH, and reflecting this, 3 was observed to form a heteronuclear species incorporating Na+ as well as Co2+. The absence of characteristic bands at 1680–1715 cm–1 in the IR spectra of these products indicates that complete deprotonation of the four carboxylic acids of H4 TCTA has occurred in each complex. The X-ray analysis of the products reveals that all show 3D infinite structures, with the TCTA unit in each complex exhibiting a saddle-shaped 1,3-alternate conformation. The variations of the supramolecular architectures in 1–4 are illustrated in Scheme .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and General Characterization

All complexes were obtained as crystalline products by the solvothermal reaction of H4 TCTA and the required metal nitrate with BPY, BPPA, or DAH in DMF. In order to successfully prepare the complexes, it was found important to maintain weakly basic reaction conditions by employing basic coligands (as well as using the basic DMF solvent); the exception was for 3. In this latter case, it was found necessary to add a small amount of NaOH, and reflecting this, 3 was observed to form a heteronuclear species incorporating Na+ as well as Co2+. The absence of characteristic bands at 1680-1715 cm-1 in the IR spectra of these products indicates that complete deprotonation of the four carboxylic acids of H4 TCTA has occurred in each complex. The X-ray analysis of the products reveals that all show 3D infinite structures, with the TCTA unit in each complex exhibiting a saddle-shaped 1,3-alternate conformation. The variations of the supramolecular architectures in 1-4 are illustrated in Scheme .

elements.content: A solvothermal reaction of H4 TCTA with Co(NO3)2·6H2O in the presence of BPY was carried out, and two kinds of crystals were obtained and identified; blue plates, 1, were obtained immediately after cooling the solution to room temperature, and then yellow crystals, 2, were obtained after 1 week following slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: A solvothermal reaction of H4 TCTA with Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O in the presence of BPY was carried out, and two kinds of crystals were obtained and identified; blue plates, 1, were obtained immediately after cooling the solution to room temperature, and then yellow crystals, 2, were obtained after 1 week following slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature.

elements.content: The X-ray crystal structure of 1 is shown in Figure , with selected geometric parameters presented in Table . Analysis of the structure reveals a 3D pillared and layered structure of formula [Co2(TCTA)(BPY)] n that is built up from dicobalt(II) paddle-wheel-shaped Co2(carboxylate)4 units. The Co···Co separation across individual paddle-wheels is 2.61(7) Å. The axis sites on each paddle-wheel are occupied by BPY linkers via Co–N bonds. Since the array of BPY and Co atoms is located on the C 4v axis of the paddle-wheel, the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a quarter of a TCTA ligand, a half of a Co atom, and a half of a BPY coligand. In the paddle-wheel unit, each Co atom is coordinated by four carboxylic oxygen atoms from four adjacent TCTA units and one nitrogen atom from a BPY bridging unit, to yield a square-pyramid geometry (Figure a). Notably, the connectivity of the paddle-wheel centers toward the four TCTA ligands generates the 2D layer, which is further pillared by the BPY to form the resulting 3D structure (Figure b–d). Since most of the space in 1, with its 3D pillared layered structure, is occupied by t-butyl groups, the effective free volume inside the thiacalix[4] cavity is small; it was calculated by PLATON to be 5.0% of the crystal volume (147.9 out of the 2949.5 Å3 unit cell volume).

The crystal structure of 2 is shown in Figure , and selected geometric parameters are presented in Table . Since the array of BPY and Co atoms locate on the C 2v axis and the 4-fold screw axis exists at the center of TCTA, the asymmetric unit of 2 consists of a quarter of a TCTA ligand, a half of Co atom, a half of a BPY coligand, and one water molecule. The Co(II) center is six-coordinated, being bound to two carboxylate oxygens from different TCTA units in a monodentate manner, and two water molecules (Figure a). The octahedral coordination sphere is completed by two additional BPY linkers via nitrogen atoms.

The BPY molecules coordinate to Co(II) centers to form BPY–Co–BPY–Co 1D chains. The 1D chains are arranged in a parallel manner on the same plane to give a 2D sheet structure stacked alternately by turning 90° in a A-B-A-B mode (Figure d). Further, these sheets are pillared by TCTA via Co–O bonds in a tetrahedral manner to afford the 3D motif. The distance between A···B layers is 11.3 Å. Attributed to the presence of the longer TCTA as a pillar molecule, in contrast to 1, the effective free volume in 2 is calculated by PLATON to be 47.0% of the crystal volume (10857.8 out of the 23125.6 Å3 unit cell volume). This void volume was filled with disordered solvent molecules whose contribution was eliminated using the SQUEEZE routine (PLATON).

elements.content: When the bent coligand BPPA was used under the same reaction conditions as used for the reaction with BPY, no solid product was obtained. Treatment of this reaction mixture with a small amount of NaOH, however, gave a violet complex of type {[Co3Na2(TCTA)2(BPPA)2(H2O)2]·4DMF·4H2O} n (3). X-ray analysis revealed that 3 features a 3D network with the presence of an endocyclic monosodium complex species linked by exocyclic cobalt atoms, which are further bridged by BPPA to give a unique heteronuclear MOF structure incorporating mixed ligands. The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of one TCTA, one BPPA, one and a half Co atoms, and a half of Na atom.
elements.clean_text: When the bent coligand BPPA was used under the same reaction conditions as used for the reaction with BPY, no solid product was obtained. Treatment of this reaction mixture with a small amount of NaOH, however, gave a violet complex of type {[Co3Na2(TCTA)2(BPPA)2(H2O)2]⋅4DMF⋅4H2O} n  (3). X-ray analysis revealed that 3 features a 3D network with the presence of an endocyclic monosodium complex species linked by exocyclic cobalt atoms, which are further bridged by BPPA to give a unique heteronuclear MOF structure incorporating mixed ligands. The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of one TCTA, one BPPA, one and a half Co atoms, and a half of Na atom.

elements.content: Interestingly, the Na atom is located inside the calix cavity in a distorted square planar array of two monodentate carboxylate oxygens and two phenolic oxygens from two different 1,3-alternate pendant groups in a cis arrangement [O–Na1–O 67.02(1)–125.89(1)°] (Figure b, Table ). The Na1 atom lies out of the square plane by 0.140 Å toward ring A, and the arrangement is also stabilized by η3-type cation···π interactions (dashed lines in Figure b) with ring A (avg distance 3.43 Å) and ring C (avg distance 3.64 Å). Interestingly, the difference in the dihedral angles between the two opposite aromatic rings A and C (33.11°) and B and D (21.72°) reflects the effect of chelation as well as the presence of cation···π interactions involving the sodium ion on the 1,3-alterante conformation adopted by TCTA.

On the other hand, the two Co atoms (Co1 and Co2), which bridge TCTA and BPPA molecules, have different coordination environments. The Co1 atom located on the inversion center is six-coordinated, being bound to two carboxylate oxygens from different TCTA ligands in a monodentate manner, and two water molecules. The octahedral coordination sphere is completed by two additional BPPA linkers via nitrogen atoms. The Co2 atom is bonded to three monodentate carboxylate oxygens from different TCTA and one BPPA through a nitrogen atom to form a distorted tetrahedral environment.

The octahedral coordination sphere is completed by two additional BPPA linkers via nitrogen atoms. The Co2 atom is bonded to three monodentate carboxylate oxygens from different TCTA and one BPPA through a nitrogen atom to form a distorted tetrahedral environment.

elements.content: As shown in Figure d, the Co2 atom is bonded to TCTA via Co2–O(carboxylate) bonds, yielding a honeycomb-shaped 2D sheet structure, which is considerably puckered due to the distorted tetrahedral geometry of each Co2 atom. Further, these sheets are pillared by Co1 atoms with the octahedral geometry being generated via Co1–O(carboxylate) and Co1–(BPPA)–Co2 bridging bonds to afford the 3D motif. The effective free volume (occupied by DMF and H2O) is calculated by PLATON as 7.4% of the crystal volume (643.9 out of the 8603.8 Å3 unit cell volume).

Further, these sheets are pillared by Co1 atoms with the octahedral geometry being generated via Co1-O(carboxylate) and Co1-(BPPA)-Co2 bridging bonds to afford the 3D motif. The effective free volume (occupied by DMF and H2O) is calculated by PLATON as 7.4% of the crystal volume (643.9 out of the 8603.8 Å3 unit cell volume).

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of H4 TCTA with Cd(NO3)2·6H2O in the presence of the flexible linker ligand DAH afforded complex 4 with formula {[Cd2(TCTA)(DAH)(DMF)2]·2DMF·2H2O} n as colorless needle-shaped crystals. The asymmetric unit of 4 consists of one TCTA, one DAH, two Cd atoms, and two DMF molecules. Two Cd atoms (Cd1 and Cd2) are connected by two carboxyl oxygens and have different coordination environments. Cd1 atom is seven-coordinated, being bound to four carboxylate oxygens from different TCTA in a bidentate manner and to one adjacent bridging carboxyl oxygen. The coordination sphere is completed by two DMF molecules. The Cd2 center is six-coordinated, being bound to four carboxylate oxygens from two different TCTA in a bidentate manner and to one adjacent bridging carboxyl oxygen as well as to one nitrogen atom from DAH. Considering the narrow bite angles of the bidentate carboxylate ions, the geometry of the Cd1 is probably best described as a distorted trigonal bipyramid with two DMF oxygens lying on the axis [O13–Cd1–O14, 161.6(3)°; Table ]. In a similar manner, the Cd2 coordination can be considered as distorted tetrahedral. The flexible coligand DAH links two Cd2 atoms. Notably, as shown in Figure d, the connectivity 3D pattern found in 4 corresponds to a PtS-like net, with a 1:1 ratio of both tetrahedral (TCTA) and square planar (center of Cd1 and Cd2) motifs. The effective free volume occupied by DMF and H2O is calculated by PLATON to be 1.8% of the crystal volume (117.4 out of the 6654.4 Å3 unit cell volume).

TGA experiments were performed on crystal samples of each compound without pretreatment (Figure ). From the first plateau, it can be concluded that 1 is stable to 300 °C. However, in contrast, 2 showed decomposition from slightly above ambient temperature (this result not shown in Figure ). In the cases of 3 and 4, solvent molecules were released as the samples were heated. Thus, for example, 3 appears to lose four lattice water molecules at 70–120 °C (calcd 2.3%, obsd 2.2%) and two coordinated water and four lattice DMF molecules at 140–240 °C (calcd 10.4%, obsd 10.1%). Compound 4 shows a weight loss of 11.3% over 80–240 °C, corresponding to the loss of two lattice water and two lattice DMF molecules, as well as two coordinated DMF molecules (calcd 11.2%). The lattices in compounds 1, 3, and 4 appear stable up to 300 °C but upon further heating, the structures begin to collapse, presumably reflecting the loss of ligand molecules.

elements.content: In the presence of neutral bridging coligands, thiacalix[4]arene tetraacetic acid was used for the first time to construct metal–organic frameworks under solvothermal conditions. Namely, the present study provides the first examples of thiacalix[4]arene-derivative-based 3D coordination networks that also include different types of linker ligands. The tetracarboxylate groups appended to the 1,3-alternate backbone of the thiacalix[4]arene scaffold play a key role in the observed assembly reactions. Also the structural diversity of the respective products is related to the different shapes of the bridging coligands employed. For example, the straight coligand BPY acts as a rod-like pillar or forms a layer unit via the strict bridging mode, resulting in 3D networks with simpler structures. Unlike BPY, BPPA and DAH give unusual 3D coordination networks with complicated structures due to their bent or flexible nature. Since this general approach has the potential to construct other interesting frameworks, a further investigation aimed at the production of new network compounds displaying a range of interesting topologies is in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In the presence of neutral bridging coligands, thiacalix[4]arene tetraacetic acid was used for the first time to construct metal-organic frameworks under solvothermal conditions. Namely, the present study provides the first examples of thiacalix[4]arene-derivative-based 3D coordination networks that also include different types of linker ligands. The tetracarboxylate groups appended to the 1,3-alternate backbone of the thiacalix[4]arene scaffold play a key role in the observed assembly reactions. Also the structural diversity of the respective products is related to the different shapes of the bridging coligands employed. For example, the straight coligand BPY acts as a rod-like pillar or forms a layer unit via the strict bridging mode, resulting in 3D networks with simpler structures. Unlike BPY, BPPA and DAH give unusual 3D coordination networks with complicated structures due to their bent or flexible nature. Since this general approach has the potential to construct other interesting frameworks, a further investigation aimed at the production of new network compounds displaying a range of interesting topologies is in progress.

A mixture of H4 TCTA (20 mg, 0.021 mmol), BPY (7 mg, 0.045 mmol), and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (14 mg, 0.048 mmol) dissolved in DMF (2 mL) was placed in a 5 mL Pyrex glass tube and sealed. The tube was kept at 110 °C for 48 h, followed by cooling to room temperature over 5 h. Two kinds of crystals (both suitable for X-ray analysis) were obtained; blue plates, 1, were obtained immediately after cooling to room temperature, and then yellow crystals, 2, were obtained after 1 week following slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature.
